Award.AwardTitle: Stress State, Strain History and Microstructural Effects in Ductile Fracture

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ductile fracture is a ubiquitous mode of failure in metals and some polymers whose main function is load bearing. Predicting material failure is essential to many engineering applications, including those in transportation, energy and manufacturing. Current understanding of ductile fracture is based on a theory of microvoid growth which is unable to rationalize the type of failures observed in various manufacturing or penetration processes, or the fracture of technologically important, lightweight materials. This award supports fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for the development or robust models and simulation tools of ductile fracture in structural materials under loading conditions for which yet no satisfactory solution exists. As one potential benefit, the research outcomes will aid in the development of strong and tough lightweight materials in transportation vehicles, which will ultimately lead to less fuel consumption and reduced emissions with a positive impact on the environment. The outreach activities will create an interdisciplinary and international research environment for both undergraduate and graduate students through interactions with French and Qatari laboratories. In addition, the developed simulation software will be made available to researchers and engineers through a GNU licensing process. The PI plans to document the results in a monograph on the subject matter.

One of the most challenging problems the mechanics of materials community presently faces is the prediction of failure in advanced metallic materials, particularly at low stress triaxiality where seemingly important effects of the third stress invariant have been noticed. So far, the community has responded to this challenge by developing empirical failure criteria or ad hoc extensions of existing void growth models. The Lode parameter (L) and the stress triaxiality both are considered. The present research will help answer important questions such as: (i) What is the origin of the Lode effect? (ii) How to apportion the intrinsic effects of the Lode parameter (L) among void nucleation, growth and coalescence? (iii) How to quantify the extrinsic (or apparent) effect of L on the occurrence of plastic instabilities? Answers will be provided using a micromechanical modeling approach that is true to the physics of the fracture phenomena at the governing length scales. A computational implementation of the model will be conducted and the model prediction will be tested against available and newly acquired experimental data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project tackled applied and fundamental aspects of fracture in structural components made of ductile materials, such as metals. Mitigating ductile fracture is critical to ensuring safe operation of the nation?s infrastructure, limiting material waste in manufacturing, and developing fracture-resistant advanced structural materials. Focus was laid on fracture under low stress triaxiality. Such conditions are met, for example, in thin-walled structures or under shear-dominated loadings. Thin-walled structures have long been analyzed in weight-critical applications, such as air and land vehicles, but related challenges have resurfaced in other sectors, such as pressure vessels, in particular for oil and gas transportation, or in small-scale structures. Shear-dominated loadings, on the other hand, arise in a host of metalworking operations, high-speed machining, welding and joining, earthquake-induced loading of connections in buildings, ballistic penetration, etc.

 

Project activities involved experiments as well as modeling and simulation. The main outcomes may be grouped in two categories. In the first, a critical evaluation of a class of popular models was conducted emphasizing among other things the effects of load path changes, induced anisotropy and onset of structural instabilities. Experiments play a key role in any field of science and engineering. They serve as basis for establishing key facts, and for providing data for model development, identification and assessment. Yet, the limitations of experiments in the field of ductile fracture are underestimated and understated. Models are pervasive in the literature which posit fracture criteria based on experimental measurements of strains to failure for a given stress state. One outcome of this research has been that much of what is reported in the experimental literature as a fracture locus (fracture strain versus some measures of stress state) is only apparent, and not intrinsic to the material. This finding is critically important because actual strains to fracture may be much lower than one would predict based on positing an intrinsic fracture locus. In general, critical strain based fracture criteria were found to be inadequate.

 

The main outcome of this project rests on developing models of ductile fracture under shear-dominated loadings from first principles of micromechanics. The micromechanical basis ensures that a minimum number of fracture-model parameters are involved (technically none) and that the fracture criteria rely on physically observable and measurable state variables. By construction, therefore, such models lend themselves to being verified or falsified. The developed model is described as a hybrid multi-surface model of ductile fracture whereby void growth and void coalescence are both accounted for on a sound mechanics basis. The project outcomes in this regard include in-house and finite-element codes, yet to be validated, for structural computations involving fracture at arbitrary triaxiality. One characteristic of the modeling approach is that it accounts for the anisotropy induced by loading at low triaxiality. While isotropic models are generally preferred in the engineering practice, it was found that no isotropic model could provide a physically viable rationale for fracture under shear-dominated loadings. Thus, structural engineers should be equipped with the knowledge and tools that allow them to design and analyze with anisotropy and make decisions on that basis.

 

 

More broadly, understanding the competing mechanisms of ductile fracture by internal cavitation or by plastic instability pervades beyond structural mechanics, in particular to geomechanics where shear fractures and void formation in ductile rocks in the lower and middle parts of the Earth?s crust are key mechanisms in plate tectonics. The project has thus opened new avenues of collaborative research in geophysics with colleagues at Texas A&M University.

 

The project has involved two undergraduate minority students in research, both of whom have pursued graduate school. The project has also enabled to engage all participants in international collaborations with two leadings institutions in France. Material developed in the course of the project as well as fundamental notions about ductile fracture have enhanced a summer school on computational materials science across the scales, organized at Texas A&M University. Two major review papers have been co-authored by the PI. Along with an earlier monograph, these have served as the main material for a new graduate course on Failure Mechanics of Engineering Materials established at Texas A&M University with broad participation from aerospace, mechanical, civil and materials science and engineering students.

Modified by: Ahmed-Amine Benzerga

Images (1 of )
  • Typical fracture surfaces of metals failing in (a) tension, and (b) shear. (c) Schematic dilational shear band and (d) representative cell excised from it after deformation. (e,f) Three scenarios predicted by micromechanical model. (g) Schematics of predicted formation of parabolic dimples.
    Torki and Benzerga, Extreme Mechanics Letters, Vol 23, pp, 67-71
    Public Domain
    Ahmed-Amine Benzerga
    Failure in Shear
  • (a) Round notched (RN) and plane strain notched (PN) bars. (b) Simulation-guided notch design so as to keep stress triaxiality (shown) roughly same as the Lode parameter varies from -1 (RN) to 0 (PN). (c,d) Strain to failure versus Lode parameter. (e,f) Basic idea of micromechanical modeling.
    Herrington and Benzerga, In preparation
    Public Domain
    Ahmed-Amine Benzerga
    Indirect Lode Effect
